rocks.bastion.core

Class BastionBuilderImpl<MODEL>

  • java.lang.Object
    • rocks.bastion.core.BastionBuilderImpl<MODEL>
  • Type Parameters:
    MODEL - The response model type currently bound to the builder
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    AssertionsBuilder<MODEL>, BastionBuilder<MODEL>, BindBuilder, CallbackBuilder<MODEL>, ExecuteRequestBuilder<MODEL>, PostExecutionBuilder<MODEL>, BastionEventPublisher, ResponseDecodersRegistrar

    public class BastionBuilderImpl<MODEL>
extends Object
implements BastionBuilder<MODEL>, ResponseDecodersRegistrar, BastionEventPublisher, PostExecutionBuilder<MODEL>
    The standard implementation of the BastionBuilder. Will keep state of the various attributes that a user supplies to Bastion when specifying a request. Bastion users will not typically have to deal with this class directly but will instead interact with Bastion through the various builder interfaces and the front facing Bastion facade.

      • setSuppressAssertions

        public void setSuppressAssertions(boolean suppressAssertions)
        Sets whether assertions should be suppressed for this Bastion request. When assertions are suppressed, Bastion will not execute whatever assertions were passed in to the withAssertions(Assertions) method.
        Parameters:
        suppressAssertions - true to suppress assertions; false, otherwise.

      • call

        public PostExecutionBuilder<? extends MODEL> call()
        Description copied from interface: ExecuteRequestBuilder
        Instructs Bastion to perform the HTTP request, decode the response into a model, perform any assertions and execute the registered callback. If you are using the BastionRunner, the actual call will appear as a test in any test harness GUI you are using. This is true, even if the test fails in which case the singular Bastion request which failed will appear in the GUI.

        If the call was successful, you can obtain the response received by Bastion by chaining further methods to this method. Notably, the PostExecutionBuilder.getModel() will return the decoded model and PostExecutionBuilder.getResponse() will return the complete response object (including the model) which represents the HTTP information.
        Specified by:
        call in interface ExecuteRequestBuilder<MODEL>
        Returns:
        A Bastion fluent-builder which allows you to retrieve the HTTP response and the decoded model

      • bind

        public <T> AssertionsBuilder<? extends T> bind(Class<T> modelType)
        Description copied from interface: BindBuilder
        Binds the specified class type to this Bastion builder. Although not necessarily required by Bastion, you should pass in a constructable type (a non-abstract class which can be instantiated) because the various decoders used by Bastion, such as the Jackson JSON parser, only work if it can construct an instance of the model.

        The bound type will be used further on when the user specifies assertions, callbacks or outright retrieves the decoded response model as the bound model (of the correct type) will be provided by Bastion.
        Specified by:
        bind in interface BindBuilder
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of model to bind this builder to
        Parameters:
        modelType - A non-null class type which will be used when constructing the response model
        Returns:
        A builder bound to the specified model type. Use this to continue chaining method calls and specify your Bastion test even further

      • withAssertions

        public CallbackBuilder<? extends MODEL> withAssertions(Assertions<? super MODEL> assertions)
        Description copied from interface: AssertionsBuilder
        Add an assertions object which determines whether the received response is as expected. We recommend supplying the Assertions object as a lambda or using one of the convenience implementations of Assertions (such as JsonResponseAssertions) that will take care of the most common verifications that a user would want to perform on a request.

        If this method is not called on the builder, then a no-operation assertions object which always pass are set by default.
        Specified by:
        withAssertions in interface AssertionsBuilder<MODEL>
        Parameters:
        assertions - A non-null Assertions object
        Returns:
        A fluent-builder which will allow you to add callbacks, execute the HTTP request and retrieve the response information

      • thenDo

        public ExecuteRequestBuilder<? extends MODEL> thenDo(Callback<? super MODEL> callback)
        Description copied from interface: CallbackBuilder
        Attach a callback function to this Bastion test. The callback function will be executed after a response has been received, it has been decoded into a model object and any assertions have passed.

        If this method is not called on the current Bastion builder, then a no-operations callback function which does nothing will be set by default.
        Specified by:
        thenDo in interface CallbackBuilder<MODEL>
        Parameters:
        callback - A callback function to execute after this Bastion test's assertions have passed
        Returns:
        A fluent-builder which will allow you to execute the request and then retrieve the response

      • getModel

        public MODEL getModel()
        Description copied from interface: PostExecutionBuilder
        Returns the model object that was decoded from the received HTTP response. If a type has been bound to this builder using BindBuilder.bind(Class), then the model given by this method will be of the specified type. Otherwise, the type of model will be determined by Bastion itself depending on the content-type of the response.
        Specified by:
        getModel in interface PostExecutionBuilder<MODEL>
        Returns:
        The decoded model object

      • getResponse

        public ModelResponse<? extends MODEL> getResponse()
        Description copied from interface: PostExecutionBuilder
        Returns the complete HTTP response as received. This response will contain the HTTP status code, the content-type and any HTTP headers. The response will also contain the raw response content as well as the decoded model object (which you can get directly using PostExecutionBuilder.getModel()).
        Specified by:
        getResponse in interface PostExecutionBuilder<MODEL>
        Returns:
        The full HTTP response object

      • registerModelConverter

        public void registerModelConverter(ResponseDecoder decoder)
        Description copied from interface: ResponseDecodersRegistrar
        Registers the specified ResponseDecoder for use with Bastion.
        Specified by:
        registerModelConverter in interface ResponseDecodersRegistrar
        Parameters:
        decoder - A non-null response decoder object
